On Tuesday 01 July 2003 14:51, Vincent D Murphy wrote:
> On Tuesday, Jul 1, 2003, at 16:41 Europe/Dublin, Tyler Close wrote:
> > As a simple demonstration of this, note that it not feasible for
> > you to create hyperlinks to any of the "resources" in your online
> > bank account.
>
> excuse me for butting in, but why not?
>
> example:
>
> To: support@...
> From: me@...
> Subject: problem transaction
>
> Hello,
>
> a person i made a payment to yesterday (see
> http://www.acmebank.com/accounts/me@.../payments/123/ ) has
> been seen implementing a RESTless web service.  please cancel
> this payment immediately.
>
> thanks,
> me
>
> --END
>
> i and the bank may be the only people who can GET representations of
> that payment resource, but i don't believe that makes it any less
> feasible to hyperlink to it (as i more or less did in that silly
> email).  a court who wanted to GET a representation could order the
> bank to supply it given that URI.
>
> am i missing the point?

You are very close to the point. You just demonstrated an
important use of giving user-specific resources their own URI. I
am arguing in favour of this.

I am arguing against URIs like
<http://www.acmebank.com/accounts/current/12/>, where this URI
refers the 12th most recent payment made by a particular user.

Tyler
